By MICHAEL WEISSMAN
Yesterday Dr. Malcolm
Peterson was named new dean of
the planned allied health school
for nursing and other health
services.
Peterson, who has served as
Director of the Johns Hopkins
Health Services and Research
Development Center since 1969,
is charged with he selection of
key staff and a core curriculum
for the school, as well as the fund
raising.
Peterson was chosen by an
advisory board which was picked
last September by former
president Milton Eisenhower. Dr.
Steven Muller headed the
ten-man committee, which was
made up mostly of doctors from
the East Baltimore campus.
Formation of the school was

approved in principle in
September by the Board of
Trustees, provided that new.
outside money could be found to
support the school.

have major responsibility for

or not," said Hall.

family health, radiological and
clinical laboratory sciences. It

emphasis on behaviorial sciences
and methods of health care
organization.

University's strong commitment

school's programs will make use

By WARREN GULIN
At its Monday meeting the
Student Council .expressed
dissatisfaction with the activities
now planned for April's Hopkins
Fair, and may cancel them after a
meeting 'with administration

symphony groups.

Galambos:'struggling at 40
By ROBERT PAULUS
Out of breath from climbing
the stairs of Schaffer Hall tco
fast, he charges into the
Classroom, removing the army
topcoat and flipping open the
bulky attache case almost
simultaneously.
Like some field commander,
he intensely studies the
conflicting models and probes his
subordinates for possible
alternatives.
Louis Galambos is not an army
commander, however, but a
history professor who is deeply
involved in the problems of
American economic history. The
project he directs is not an army
field operation but the editing of
the Eisenhower Papers.
Dr. Galambos functions
effectively in the dual role as
teacher and editor. As editor of
the Eisenhower Papers, he
controls the operations of
collecting, annotating and
Publishing the complete papers
of the late Dwight David

Eisenhower. So.jar. five volumes
on the "war years" have been
.published and a three volume
edition of the post war period
will be completed soon.
Backed In
Galambos didn't begin in
economic history, he "backed in
to it." Having no previous
contact with advanced economics.
or math, he became interested in
the organizational history of
business sometime in his college
career. Today he calls himself a
"broker" hg..economic history.
"I'm a middleman, trying to
achieve the best of both worlds
of traditional economic history
and the new econometrics."
While he feels that the new
quantitative approach to history
is important, he thinks that the
future will be dominated by
behavioral history and radical
revisionism.
Although his teaching and
editing take up the major portion
of his time, Galambos still finds
time to study the public response

to big business in America
between 1880 and 1940. He is
pa rticularily interested in the
long-run changes in people's
perceptions.
The high. nasal twang in his
voice reveals his mid-western
heritage. Raised in southern
Indiana along the Ohio River,
Galambos attended Purdue
before serving in the Navy during
the Korean War. Undergraduate
work at Indiana University and
,Ohio State led him to Yale. He
finished his doctorate studies at
the Harvard Business School.
Having taught at Rice and
Rutgers, Dr. Galambos is
currently teaching for the third
time at Hopkins.

Executives of termpaper firms
write off moral and legal attacks
By BILL ABBOTT
In what may be a test case for
many colleges and universities
across the nation, New York
Attorney General Louis M.
Leflcowitz filed suit last week
seeking to enjoin term paper
firms from operating in tfy: New
York City area. Executives at
two term paper firms currently
advertising in the News-letter
claim they will fight any. legal
action brought against them.
If Lefkowitz succeeds in
Obtaining an injunction, the
Georgetown Voice reports that
Georgetown University will
seriously consider doing the same
thing in Washington. Another
legal alternative being considered
at Harvard is to levy damage suits
against such firms in the event
that plagiarism can be traced
back to them.
Arts and Sciences Dean George
Benton said Hopkins does not
intend to take legal action against
the firms or to pressure the
News-Letter into not publishing
the ads. "I would be pleased to
see the state take action,"
Benton commented, "and this
matter should be handled by
them, not the university.
Conceivably we could censor the
News-Letter but I would oppose
such action under any
circumstances."
In regard to a petition signed
by 1175 members of the Hopkins
community "deploring the use of
University facilities" for
promoting the firms, Benton
suggested "they ought to petition
the News-Letter."
Al Peterson, Vice President
and Sales Manager of Term
Papers Unlimited, contends his
firm operates within the
framework of the law "in the
same way as a small
encyclopedia company."
Peterson admits that squdents

who use his iervices "defeat tne
purpose of going to school"
when they hand in the finished
copy provided by Term Papers
Unlimited, but claims he
"cannot believe anyone
interested enough to attend
college" would do so.
Term Papers Unlimited boasts
1,000 writers who are "specialists
in their field." Peterson freely
states that all papers they write
are in finished form and "could
easily be handed in" as a
student's own work, but he also
maintains they are solelj,
reference guides.
Harry McNulty, a grad student
in political science and a top
executive with Research Papers
Unlimited, contends his firm
offers a "sincere service" as well
as a "valuable lesson to society"
because most colleges and
universities overemphasize
research in education.

"I won't deny the profit
motive," McNulty declared,"but
the greatest prostitution is posed
by the academic community. Our
institutions of higher learning
have gotten into research too
deeply, and the fact that
corporations like this can spring
into multi -million dollar
operations is ample evidence of
the point."
"I myself would never use
such a firm," McNulty
continued, "but it's not my job
to force my morality on other
people. It's like a Jew setting up
a store in a protestant area selling
pork."
McNulty would like to donate
his profits to social causes
advancing reform. But he still
maintains "when you are
spreading knowledge, you are not
a detriment."

Muscular student demonstrates steady feet and firm grip in difficult
climb up the ROTC rappeling tower.

By PAUL MICHAELIS
The long-haired student
grimaces as he struggles to climb
the ropes to the top of the tower.
But he is not in a Marine boot
camp. Instead, he is on the
Homewood campa, part of a
unique class of 50 students
learning wilderness skills.
The rope-climbing skill learned
on the rappeling tower behind
the ROTC building is just one
part of the course offered by the
Physical Education and Military
Science Departments this
semester. The group of would-be
woodsmen include eight women
and two Hopkins professors. It is
one of the few courses of this
type offered on an American
college campus.
The course aims to help
students gain confidence and
overcome fears, in addition to
teaching them the fundamentals
of wilderness navigation and
survival. Among the topics
covered are stream-crossing
techniques, rappeling,
orienteering, swimming and
survival. Many of these skills will
prove useful on their two
scheduled overnight field trips to
Patapsco Park.
In the Wilds
And they will need all the
wilderness skills they can learn.
In the wilds of the park, far from
a Howard Johnson Motor Lodge,
they will be required to orient
themselves using only maps and
compasses. Then, step by step,

inch by inch, they will follow a
daredevil course which includes
an 85 foot cliff and a stream

East Balto. drug rehabilitation center closes
By STEPHEN TULLOSS
As a result of the closing of
Hopkins' East Baltimore drug
rehabilitation program, five or
more patients paroled to Project
Exit may have to return to
prison, and the East Baltimore
area will be left without a
sponsored drug rehabilitation
center.
Conflicting accounts have been
presented in explanation of the
closing, but there is a clear
consensus that, in the words of
Dr. Torrey Brown, who was
assistant director of the project,
"It was a tragedy without a
villain."
An account published in the
News-American points to a
communications breakdown
between Project Exit's therapist
Freda Foster, program director
Dr. Garrett O'Connor, and the
Maryland State Drug Abuse
Administration. Brown, who
became director of the project
when O'Connor left Hopkins
recently, denies the
News-American account.
Lack of Facilities
"More than anything else, it
was the lack of facilities which
killed Project Exit," said Brown.
Although Foster agreed that
Exit's greatest disadvantage while
in operation was a lack of
facilities, she holds that
"politics" dealt the program its
deathblow, and that Project
Exit's potential benefits lost a

battle with East Baltimore's
vested interests.
Foster maintained that
essentially irrelevant incidents
contributed to Hopkins' closing
of the rehabilitation center.
"While we were fighting to get
materials to keep the center
open, there was a lot of tension
both in the patients and in the
staff....One of the residents shot
a hole through the floor...one of
the staff pulled a knife on
another staff member..there was
an incident involving a
homosexual resident." Brown
denied that any of these
incidents influenced the
Hospital's decision to terminate
the Exit center.
Abstinence
Project Exit was the first
resident drug rehabilitation
center in East Baltimore, and also
the first to work toward total
withdrawal. Methadone, Foster
pointed out, is even more
iddicting than heroin; Project
Exit's philosophy encourages
total abstinence from all drugs
and alchohol.
The project was of special
significance since its Hopkins
backing, among other factors,
made it possible for drug
offenders to be paroled to the
project. At the time of the
project's termination, several
parolees were living at the center;
they may have to return to jail.

Foster described herself as
bewildered by the fact that the
program was closed even though
there were ample funds .to
continue it until the end of June.
Didn't Work
"The major reason for closing
down the center was simply that
it didn't work," said Brown. He
cited Hopkins' administrative
figures showing that of over 100
entrants to the program, only six
completed the full tour at Project
Exit, and that of those six,
probably half are back on drugs.
"Although I have nothing but
respect and admiration for Freda
(Foster), Brown said, "the fact
remains that because of the
circumstances — the problems
with buildings and facilities — the
program was not effective."
According to Foster, only
about one-third of Brown's
hundred entrants ever appeared
at Project Exit's residences, and
of those, many left too quickly
to have recieved any meaningful
treatment. "Most of our time,
both the patients' and the staffs
went to menial labor — trying to
make these buildings fit to live
in. There wasn't the time or
energy to work on the goals of
the program."
Movin' On
At the time of its termination,
Project Exit was in its third
home, a rowhouse in the 800
block of North Broadway. Two

other buildings were left because
of their dilapidated condition',
and, according to Brown, some
neighborhood resistance. "We
spent an incredible amount of
time hustling furniture and
equipment," said Foster. She
claims that the assistance
provided by Hopkins was
absolutely minimal, sufficing
only for salaries and food.
As of last week, Hopkins
Hospital had laid claim to the
Exit house's furnishings and
equipment, which were privately
donated to Project Exit through
the efforts of Foster and the
staff. The remaining funding for
the project is slated for a drug
rehabilitation project which will

be sponsored by the East
Baltimore Community
Corporation. A second existing
East Baltimore rehabilitation
project, Xcell, has access to the
house itself.
There are presently no plans
for another Hopkins Hospital
drug rehabilitation residence,
although Dr. Brown says that he
is willing to support a second
effort. "If someone came in
tomorrow and said, 'Would you
like a house for forty people?'
we'd jump at the chance.
Everyone is terriblY
disappointed; everyone had an
enormous amount of time and
effort in the project."

By ROBERT PAULUS
Out of breath from climbing
the stairs of Schaffer Hall tco
fast, he charges into the
Classroom, removing the army
topcoat and flipping open the
bulky attache case almost
simultaneously.
Like some field commander,
he intensely studies the
conflicting models and probes his
subordinates for possible
alternatives.
Louis Galambos is not an army
commander, however, but a
history professor who is deeply
involved in the problems of
American economic history. The
project he directs is not an army
field operation but the editing of
the Eisenhower Papers.
Dr. Galambos functions
effectively in the dual role as
teacher and editor. As editor of
the Eisenhower Papers, he
controls the operations of
collecting, annotating and
Publishing the complete papers
of the late Dwight David

Eisenhower. So.jar. five volumes
on the "war years" have been
.published and a three volume
edition of the post war period
will be completed soon.
Backed In
Galambos didn't begin in
economic history, he "backed in
to it." Having no previous
contact with advanced economics.
or math, he became interested in
the organizational history of
business sometime in his college
career. Today he calls himself a
"broker" hg..economic history.
"I'm a middleman, trying to
achieve the best of both worlds
of traditional economic history
and the new econometrics."
While he feels that the new
quantitative approach to history
is important, he thinks that the
future will be dominated by
behavioral history and radical
revisionism.
Although his teaching and
editing take up the major portion
of his time, Galambos still finds
time to study the public response

to big business in America
between 1880 and 1940. He is
pa rticularily interested in the
long-run changes in people's
perceptions.
The high. nasal twang in his
voice reveals his mid-western
heritage. Raised in southern
Indiana along the Ohio River,
Galambos attended Purdue
before serving in the Navy during
the Korean War. Undergraduate
work at Indiana University and
,Ohio State led him to Yale. He
finished his doctorate studies at

Loveland's Baby Jays whip the Greyhounds
The Hopkins' freshman
basketball team capped their
successful season last week with
an 83-68 victory over Loyola.
This win, the sixth straight for
the Baby Jays, gave them eleven
on the season against only two
losses, the latter coming at the
hands of Navy and Drexel.
Coach Joe Loveland piloted
the team to their best record in
recent years and is
understandably proud of the
accomplishments of his players.
Loveland's team responded to
his efforts with steller
performances. The Baby Jays
netted 45% of their shots from
the floor and pulled down an
average of 51 rebounds a game.

The rebounding strength was
particularly apparent in Hopkins'
last three games, when they
grabbed 67, 65, and 65 caroms
respectively. This combination of
strong shooting and control of
the backboards at both ends of
the court proved too much for
the opposition throughout the
season.
Another important factor in
the squad's success was the
strong bench that gave Coach
Loveland the depth required to
regularly use an effective full
court press without overtaxing
his players.
After adjusting to the team's
capabilities, Loveland instituted a
flexible substitution system that

allowed each player to
aggressively play all out while on
the court, which is important to
a running team like Hopkins.
Quarterbacking
Quarterbacking the squad was
guard Paul Spence, who led the
team in scoring with a 17.8 point
average, hitting 55% of his
attempted shots and scoring on
50 free throws. More indicative
of his leadership ability was his
role as the team's playmaker,
evidenced by the fact that he had
60 assists over the season, which
was twelve more than the next
highest figure.
Greg DeLong was another key
to the Baby Jay season. His 93

field goals was a high for the
team, and his rebounding was
also exceptional. DeLong picked
off an average of 10 stray shots a
game from his forward position.
Other important cogs in the
board clearing machine were
center John Sauter and Forward
Tom Davis, who combined to
grab 203 rebounds.
Defense was another strength
of the freshmen. As a unit, the
Baby Jays presented each
opponent with any one of several
defenses. Coach Loveland
worked primarily with a tight

10301 zone and an oppressive
man-to-man that defused many
attacks. Shifting frequently
between these two, the full court
press, and other defensive
variations, Loveland befuddled
many of the Blue Jays

East Balto. drug rehabilitation center closes
By STEPHEN TULLOSS
As a result of the closing of
Hopkins' East Baltimore drug
rehabilitation program, five or
more patients paroled to Project
Exit may have to return to
prison, and the East Baltimore
area will be left without a
sponsored drug rehabilitation
center.
Conflicting accounts have been
presented in explanation of the
closing, but there is a clear
consensus that, in the words of
Dr. Torrey Brown, who was
assistant director of the project,
"It was a tragedy without a
villain."
An account published in the
News-American points to a
communications breakdown
between Project Exit's therapist
Freda Foster, program director
Dr. Garrett O'Connor, and the
Maryland State Drug Abuse
Administration. Brown, who
became director of the project
when O'Connor left Hopkins
recently, denies the
News-American account.
Lack of Facilities
"More than anything else, it
was the lack of facilities which
killed Project Exit," said Brown.
Although Foster agreed that
Exit's greatest disadvantage while
in operation was a lack of
facilities, she holds that
"politics" dealt the program its
deathblow, and that Project
Exit's potential benefits lost a

battle with East Baltimore's
vested interests.
Foster maintained that
essentially irrelevant incidents
contributed to Hopkins' closing
of the rehabilitation center.
"While we were fighting to get
materials to keep the center
open, there was a lot of tension
both in the patients and in the
staff....One of the residents shot
a hole through the floor...one of
the staff pulled a knife on
another staff member..there was
an incident involving a
homosexual resident." Brown
denied that any of these
incidents influenced the
Hospital's decision to terminate
the Exit center.
Abstinence
Project Exit was the first
resident drug rehabilitation
center in East Baltimore, and also
the first to work toward total
withdrawal. Methadone, Foster
pointed out, is even more
iddicting than heroin; Project
Exit's philosophy encourages
total abstinence from all drugs
and alchohol.
The project was of special
significance since its Hopkins
backing, among other factors,
made it possible for drug
offenders to be paroled to the
project. At the time of the
project's termination, several
parolees were living at the center;
they may have to return to jail.

Foster described herself as
bewildered by the fact that the
program was closed even though
there were ample funds .to
continue it until the end of June.
Didn't Work
"The major reason for closing
down the center was simply that
it didn't work," said Brown. He
cited Hopkins' administrative
figures showing that of over 100
entrants to the program, only six
completed the full tour at Project
Exit, and that of those six,
probably half are back on drugs.
"Although I have nothing but
respect and admiration for Freda
(Foster), Brown said, "the fact
remains that because of the
circumstances — the problems
with buildings and facilities — the
program was not effective."
According to Foster, only
about one-third of Brown's
hundred entrants ever appeared
at Project Exit's residences, and
of those, many left too quickly
to have recieved any meaningful
treatment. "Most of our time,
both the patients' and the staffs
went to menial labor — trying to
make these buildings fit to live
in. There wasn't the time or
energy to work on the goals of
the program."
Movin' On
At the time of its termination,
Project Exit was in its third
home, a rowhouse in the 800
block of North Broadway. Two

other buildings were left because
of their dilapidated condition',
and, according to Brown, some
neighborhood resistance. "We
spent an incredible amount of
time hustling furniture and
equipment," said Foster. She
claims that the assistance
provided by Hopkins was
absolutely minimal, sufficing
only for salaries and food.
As of last week, Hopkins
Hospital had laid claim to the
Exit house's furnishings and
equipment, which were privately
donated to Project Exit through
the efforts of Foster and the
staff. The remaining funding for
the project is slated for a drug
rehabilitation project which will

be sponsored by the East
Baltimore Community
Corporation. A second existing
East Baltimore rehabilitation
project, Xcell, has access to the
house itself.
There are presently no plans
for another Hopkins Hospital
drug rehabilitation residence,
although Dr. Brown says that he
is willing to support a second
effort. "If someone came in
tomorrow and said, 'Would you
like a house for forty people?'
we'd jump at the chance.
Everyone is terriblY
disappointed; everyone had an
enormous amount of time and
effort in the project."
